title: What's your ideal game length?
body:
What's your ideal game length? I'm asking because people seem to prefer short games, which I don't understand at all. At the 50 min mark, it's fair to say each team has had a shot to win, no?

Anyway, I thank you for your vote in advance.

replies.body:
Personally? 40-45. Those games a ton of fun. You can feel the tension all over the place. You know the winners earned the victory.

But I'm perfectly happy to settle for an average of 35, since I know not everyone likes those super long games. And they're probably better for balance when champions like Pantheon exist.

However, the current shitfest that is 25 fucking minutes? Unacceptable.
I chose 40-45, but I'd be happy with 35-45

It's been cool to watch the discussion around this!

I voted for 30-35, which feels like a happy medium to me. I also love the nail-biters that go 50 and up, but I think I'd get tired of that pretty quick if it happened every game.

Personally it seems that games are supposed to go about 35-40 minutes and that is where I like them myself. If it wasn't, they would not have late game hypercarries.

And that is one of the problems with this preseason. Game is tuned to be longer than the 0-25 minute crapfests that are happening on average now.

For me personally I would like 5% to be 20-25 minutes. 5% to be 55-60 minutes and the rest in between with the bulk at 35-45 minutes. 

Imho champions should not be considered late game if they are on their second item. (worlds 2017 with the IE static shiv 'late game' twitch anyone?) 35 minutes in my opinion is where midgame should be ending. People are hitting 4-5 items and transitioning into late game where the likes of trist twitch kog vayne and gangplank come online. 

I miss the days where tanks were super tanky and defensive items were core on adc's because they could legit get oneshot. The game felt more fun back then. Champions actually felt good to play. Fighters didn't insta die even with 4 defensive items adc's did a shit ton of damage in the late game and midgame Mundo could run through your team for 20 seconds while being focus fired on. And mages legit felt powerful. And assassins fell off really hard but made up for that with an insane early game and being able to 1v1 any mage or adc with impunity. 

I feel like we bitched about the perfect game so much we basically destroyed it. I almost never even que up anymore because it just feels like literal pain to enter the game in the state it is now.
30-35 minutes with the occasional nail biting 45-55 minute games
Fuck snowball fests. Fuck slapfight fests. The game shouldn't be a slog or a speedy dash, but somewhere in between. therefore, at least 30 mins and 40 mins at maximum.

I used to play starcraft 2 before this game so I can't really compare to what this game was, but I can definitely tell that it seems to be making the same mistakes starcraft has.

It seems to be focusing more on what is fun to spectate than what is fun to play. Yes watching zoe instadelete someone is fun, watching yasuo turn around a 1v1 is fun... playing against any of that? Not so much.

How does this apply to game length? People don't like watching long laning phases and long teamfight phases because they don't feel the tension of it all as much as the players. People would rather watch their favorite team roflstomp their opponents in 20 minutes.

Players on the other hand, clearly like the chance to scale and the time to come back from any early game mistakes they/their team may have made. Laning against someone that has 2 kills up on you now means they can dive 1 shot you and take 1 turret shot if you're lucky. Can you imagine how fun it would be if you could actually comeback from that via outplays most of the time? If killing someone 2 kills down on you wasn't completely effortless as it is now and took similar effort as the first 2 times, then both of the players would get a chance to play the game instead of either getting one-shot or one-shotting. 

Then the lategame has a chance of being more even because everyone had time to show their skill - if one team is truly better than the other, they will still be really far ahead, but this won't be off of just 1 or 2 mistakes by the enemy, but by a full length laning phase.

so 35-40 is a really good number for games that last long enough but not too long. Although personally I would like at least half of my games to be 40-45, because I enjoy the sense of bonding with the team in long games. 

The transition from this attitude: "gotta flash so I can KS and carry my feeding team"

To this attitude: "gotta flash into that projectile (instead of getting kill my team will secure without me) to save my adc even though it will kill me and I'll have to use flash"

is my favorite feeling in league.
